questions.question: According to the psychological principles discussed in Lesson 1, what phenomenon occurs when a client experiences mental discomfort because their behavior (consuming animal products) conflicts with their new values (animal welfare or health)?
options: Cognitive Dissonance
Confirmation Bias
The Halo Effect
Decision Fatigue
questions.explanation: Cognitive Dissonance is the psychological stress experienced by a person who holds two or more contradictory beliefs, ideas, or values. In plant-based coaching, resolving this dissonance is key to shifting identity and behavior.

questions.question: In the 'Habit Loop' framework (Cue, Craving, Response, Reward), which strategy is most effective for a client who habitually reaches for dairy-based snacks when stressed at work?
options: Using willpower to ignore the craving entirely
Eliminating the reward phase of the loop
Identifying the cue (stress) and substituting the response with a plant-based alternative
Punishing the behavior to create a negative association
questions.explanation: Lesson 2 teaches that habits are best modified by keeping the cue and the reward similar but changing the 'Response' (the behavior itself) to a more health-aligned action.

questions.question: A 2018 study by Poore and Nemecek (Oxford University) cited in Lesson 3 found that while meat and dairy provide 18% of calories, they use what percentage of global farmland?
questions.explanation: The study found that livestock takes up 83% of global farmland and produces 58% of agriculture's greenhouse gas emissions while providing only 18% of calories and 37% of protein.

questions.question: When navigating social dining (Lesson 4), the 'Host-First Strategy' recommends which of the following actions to minimize friction and ensure dietary adherence?
options: Eating a full meal before arriving so you don't have to eat anything there
Informing the host of your dietary needs 24-48 hours in advance and offering to bring a substantial dish to share
Demanding the host change the entire menu to accommodate your plant-based lifestyle
Waiting until the meal is served to explain why you cannot eat the food
questions.explanation: Proactive communication (24-48 hours) combined with the offer to contribute a dish (the 'Contribution Strategy') reduces host stress and ensures the client has a nutrient-dense option.

questions.question: Lesson 5 discusses 'Sensory-Specific Satiety.' How can a coach use this concept to help a client feel more satisfied with a plant-based meal?
options: By encouraging the client to eat the exact same meal every day
By limiting the variety of textures on the plate
By incorporating a wide variety of colors, textures, and flavors (umami, sweet, sour, salty) in a single meal
By drinking large amounts of water during the meal to distend the stomach
questions.explanation: Sensory-specific satiety refers to the decline in pleasure derived from a specific food as it is consumed. Diverse textures and flavors in plant-based meals prevent boredom and increase the 'pleasure' aspect of satiety.

questions.question: According to Self-Determination Theory (Lesson 6), which form of motivation is the strongest predictor of long-term (multi-year) adherence to a plant-based diet?
options: Extrinsic Motivation (e.g., wanting to look good for a wedding)
Introjected Regulation (e.g., eating plant-based to avoid feeling guilty)
Integrated Regulation (e.g., the diet is a core part of the person's identity and values)
External Regulation (e.g., following the diet because a doctor ordered it)
questions.explanation: Integrated regulation occurs when the behavior is fully assimilated into the person's self-identity. This internal drive is far more sustainable than external pressures or temporary goals.

questions.question: Lesson 7 explores Circadian Rhythm. Why is 'front-loading' calories (eating more in the morning/afternoon) particularly beneficial for plant-based clients managing blood glucose?
options: Insulin sensitivity is naturally higher in the morning and decreases in the evening
Plant proteins are only absorbable before 2:00 PM
Fiber takes exactly 12 hours to digest, requiring an early start
Melatonin increases the rate of fat oxidation in the morning
questions.explanation: Human metabolism follows a circadian rhythm where insulin sensitivity and the thermic effect of food are higher in the morning. Consuming carbohydrates (even complex ones) late at night can lead to higher glucose spikes.

questions.question: A client eats a piece of cheese at a party and then thinks, 'I've already ruined my plant-based diet, I might as well eat the pepperoni pizza and ice cream too.' This is an example of:
options: The All-or-Nothing Paradox
The Abstinence Violation Effect (AVE)
The Satiety Regression Loop
The Transitionary Lag Phase
questions.explanation: The Abstinence Violation Effect (AVE) occurs when a 'slip' leads to feelings of guilt and loss of control, causing the individual to abandon their dietary goals entirely for a period.

questions.question: In the context of 'Implementation Intentions' (Lesson 2), which of the following 'If-Then' statements is the most effective for a client who struggles with late-night cravings?
options: If I feel hungry at night, I will just try to go to sleep.
If it is 9:00 PM and I feel the urge to snack, then I will drink a glass of water and practice 5 minutes of mindful breathing.
I will not eat any snacks after dinner starting on Monday.
If I eat a snack, I will make sure it is a plant-based snack.
questions.explanation: Effective Implementation Intentions must be specific, include a clear cue (9:00 PM/urge to snack), and provide a concrete alternative action (water/breathing) rather than just a vague goal.

questions.question: Based on the EAT-Lancet Commission's 'Planetary Health Diet' (Lesson 3), what is the recommended daily intake of red meat for both human health and planetary sustainability?
options: 0 grams (total elimination)
Approximately 7-14 grams per day (or one serving per week)
50 grams per day
100 grams per day
questions.explanation: The EAT-Lancet Commission suggests a 'planetary health plate' that limits red meat to about 7-14 grams per day to stay within planetary boundaries and optimize health outcomes.
